data.title: Pearl Jam Dark Matter Review: Seattle giants’ twelfth album hits like a triple espresso
data.meta_description: Rolling Stones producer Andrew Watt helps focus Pearl Jam’s power on electrifying new album, Dark Matter.
data.text:
Pearl Jam

Dark Matter

★★★★

REPUBLIC

First Iggy Pop, Ozzy Osbourne and The Rolling Stones: now Pearl Jam are the latest rock institution to plug into erstwhile Justin Bieber producer Andrew Watt, a younger dude adept at refurbishing old school for the earbud generation.

READ MORE: Pearl Jam interviewed: “Taylor Swift fans reminded me of punk rock crowds”

That Dark Matter succeeds so well is due to the band focusing their creative energy, just as Watt’s sonic Nutribullet technique condenses PJ’s core rumble into punchy blasts. “We used to dance, we had our own scene,” hollers Eddie Vedder on opener Scared Of Fear, its taut-rocking meld of The Wipers and Big Star setting a tone for the manic melancholy that surges throughout these 11 songs.

Wreckage finds them “surrounded by the remnants”, a Tom Petty-styled reckoning with life, blessed with rueful harmony and hard-earned wisdom, while Got To Give is Pearl Jam’s latest and maybe greatest hymn to people power. “I’ll be the last one standing,” Vedder affirms. On this form, anything’s possible.

READ MORE: Every Pearl Jam Album Ranked!

TRACKLIST:

Scared of Fear

React, Respond

Wreckage

Dark Matter

Won’t Tell

Upper Hand

Waiting for Stevie

Running

Something Special

Got to Give

Setting Sun

Dark Matter is out now on Republic.

Listen/Buy: Spotify | Apple Music | Amazon | Rough Trade | HMV
